content_parts.text: —The prophet Jonah (commemorated September 21) is traditionally considered to be the author.
He was an inhabitant of the city of Gath Hepher (
) within the tribal borders of Zebulun, about five miles north of Nazareth.
The experience of Jonah occurred during the reign of King Jeroboam II of Israel (790–750 BC).
The compassion of the Lord is not limited to the Jews, but extends to all people, even to the enemies of God's people.
Jonah's reluctance to carry out God's command and his disappointment when God acts mercifully are a result of his narrow-minded nationalism, shared with many Jews of the postexilic period.
—The only other historical reference to Jonah comes from
, which mentions “Jonah the son of Amittai, the prophet from Gath Hepher.” In the Orthodox Church's liturgical tradition, the Book of Jonah is read in its entirety on Holy Saturday.
The third-day deliverance of Jonah from the great fish is a foretaste of the third-day Resurrection of Christ.
